container.name: Recalling
container.p: Recalling its resolutions 55/33 E of 20Â November 2000, 57/60 of 22Â November 2002, 59/93 of 3Â December 2004, 61/73 of 6Â December 2006, 63/70 of 2Â December 2008, 65/77 of 8Â December 2010, 67/47 of 3Â December 2012, 69/65 of 2Â December 2014, 71/57 of 5Â December 2016, 73/59 of 5Â December 2018, 75/61 of 7Â December 2020 and 77/52 of 7Â December 2022,

container.name: Recalling also
container.p: Recalling also that 2024 marks the twenty-fourth anniversary of resolution 55/33 E for the development of the study on disarmament and nonâproliferation education,

container.name: Recalling further
container.p: Recalling further its resolution 78/31 of 4Â December 2023 on youth, disarmament and nonâproliferation,

container.name: Welcoming
container.p:
Welcoming the report of the Secretary-General on disarmament and nonâproliferation education,
A/79/114. in which the Secretary-General reported on the implementation of the recommendations contained in the United Nations study on disarmament and nonâproliferation education,
A/57/124. and further recalling with appreciation that 2024 marks the twenty-second anniversary of that report,

container.name: Noting
container.p: Noting the highest number of submissions by Member States since the first such report in 2004,

container.name: Recognizing
container.p: Recognizing the usefulness of the disarmament and nonâproliferation education website and online resources, which are updated on a regular basis by the Office for Disarmament Affairs of the Secretariat, including to provide online courses and dynamic information on diverse disarmament issues, and encouraging the use of the advances in new information and communications technologies and social media for the promotion of disarmament and nonâproliferation education,

container.name: Emphasizing
container.p: Emphasizing that efforts need to be continued to implement the recommendations of the study, leveraging the opportunities offered by new digital technologies, and follow the good examples of how they are being implemented to stimulate even further long-term results, including the assistance of Member States to academia and civil society in their important disarmament and nonâproliferation pedagogical activities,

container.name: Desirous
container.p: Desirous of stressing the urgency of promoting concerted international efforts at disarmament and nonâproliferation, in particular in the field of nuclear disarmament and nonâproliferation, with a view to strengthening international security, confidence-building, and enhancing sustainable development,

container.name: Conscious
container.p: Conscious of the need to combat the negative effects of cultures of violence and complacency in the face of current dangers in this field through long-term programmes of education and training,

container.name: Remaining convinced
container.p: Remaining convinced that the need for disarmament and nonâproliferation education and critical thinking skills, particularly among youth, has never been greater, not only on the subject of weapons of mass destruction but also in the field of small arms and light weapons, terrorism and other challenges, including those posed by emerging technologies, to international security and the process of disarmament, as well as on the relevance of implementing the recommendations contained in the United Nations study,

container.name: Recognizing
container.p: Recognizing the importance of the participation of civil society, including academic and nonâgovernmental organizations, which plays an active role in the promotion of disarmament and nonâproliferation education, as well as in promoting the engagement of young people in the field of disarmament and nonâproliferation,

content.p: Expresses its appreciation to the Member States, the United Nations and other international and regional organizations, civil society and academic and nonâgovernmental organizations, which, within their purview, implemented the recommendations made in the United Nations study, as discussed in the report of the Secretary-General reviewing the implementation of the recommendations, and encourages them once again to continue to apply and advance those recommendations and report to the Secretary-General on steps taken to implement them;

Encourages Member States, the United Nations, relevant specialized agencies and regional and subregional organizations to continue considering developing and implementing policies and educational programmes for young people to increase and facilitate their constructive engagement in the field of disarmament and nonâproliferation;

Requests the Secretary-General to prepare a report reviewing the results of the implementation of the recommendations and possible new opportunities for promoting disarmament and nonâproliferation education, and to submit it to the General Assembly at its eighty-first session;

Reiterates its appreciation to the Secretary-General for his disarmament agenda, Securing Our Common Future: An Agenda for Disarmament, and notes the proposed actions therein to further advance disarmament and nonâproliferation education, as well as those actions championed and supported by Member States, and further notes the disarmament education strategy published by the Office for Disarmament Affairs of the Secretariat in December 2022;

Reiterates the request to the Secretary-General to utilize electronic means to the fullest extent possible in the dissemination, in as many official languages as feasible, of information related to his report and any other information that the Office for Disarmament Affairs gathers on an ongoing basis with regard to the implementation of the recommendations of the United Nations study;

Requests, in this regard, the Secretary-General to maintain and update the disarmament education online resources, including e-learning tools and related resources as efficient and effective tools to promote disarmament and nonâproliferation education;

Encourages the Secretary-General, supported by voluntary contributions, to further strengthen access to and impact of disarmament and nonâproliferation education at the global, regional and subregional levels, including through promoting networks of disarmament education experts, tailored training initiatives and educate-the-educator tools, among others, and further encourages Member States to support such efforts;

Decides to include in the provisional agenda of its eighty-first session, under the item entitled âGeneral and complete disarmamentâ, the sub-item entitled âDisarmament and nonâproliferation educationâ.
